thread.title: NSW cattle farmer capitalises on conservation tick of approval
thread.title_full: NSW cattle farmer capitalises on conservation tick of approval

author: Sean Murphy
title: NSW cattle farmer capitalises on conservation tick of approval
text:
Map: NSW 
The owner of one of Australia's oldest pastoral stations believes a recent decision to protect a third of her property with a conservation covenant will eventually increase the value of the farm and its produce. 
Clare Cannon inherited historic Woomargama Station near Holbrook in New South Wales, which was first developed in 1838. 
Her parents Gordon and Margaret Darling bought the 1,800 hectare farm more than 50 years ago and late last year she placed a third of the property under a conservation agreement with the Nature Conservation Trust (NCT). 
It means she cannot ever clear the land and must manage its endangered boxgum woodlands according to the agreement with the Trust. 
"I'm very passionate about conservation, I'm very passionate about farming, I'm very passionate about marrying the two," Ms Cannon said. 
"I think in the short term people might see this as maybe a little bit of a risky move but in the long term I think this area of the property will be the jewel in the crown of the property even from a capital value," she said. 
Woomargama produces grass fed beef from a 1,000 head herd of poll Hereford cattle and runs about 7,500 fine wool merino sheep. 
Under the terms of the covenant she is able to graze her stock in the protected area to help control exotic plants and weeds. Covenant a 'win win' for farming, biodiversity 
The NCT's chief executive officer Gary Wells said the covenants had to work with farmers. 
"We're not looking to lock up land, it's very much about finding a happy medium where it works for both biodiversity and the farming operation and in fact bringing cattle in here under an appropriate regime actually looks after the biodiversity here rather than being detrimental to it, so it's actually a win-win for the farming and the biodiversity," Mr Wells said. 
Ms Cannon believed export markets would pay a premium for her produce based on the farm's environmental credentials. 
"We produce grass fed only beef which has quite stringent accreditation so we put the steers in this country quite a lot so it's actually a symbiotic relationship between the cattle and this country," she said. 
"We've also put that Nature Conservation Trust label on our wool saying that from time to time the sheep that produce the wool that we sell graze in this covenant country managed by the Nature Conservation Trust and that's certainly provided quite a high level of interest from wool buyers particularly in Europe but also the Chinese buyers," Ms Cannon said. Photo: Cattle graze on protected pastures. (ABC News: Sean Murphy ) 
"It's all about brand reputation so we want to be at the high end, I think that's the only place to be." 
The Woomargama covenant is a boonto science according to Charles Sturt University professor of ecology, David Watson. 
"It's one of the most pristine, best managed grassy woodlands in southern Australia," Professor Watson said. 
"It's boxgumgrassy woodlands, it's a desperately rare kind of habitat and these bits left are precious because they're not in national parks, national parks are in country that was left uncleared that nobody wanted but this place has been so well managed for so long we're all now benefitting from it." 
He said the economic benefits of conservation estates were now being quantified: such as the impact of more bird life on insect populations or how more tree cover could protect livestock from extreme weather. 
"There's insectivorous birds there that eat grasshoppers out in the field, well can you measure that, can you tell me how much more grass I'm getting, how much more meat I can produce and we're doing that now," he said. 
"If you're talking about far less winds, lower wind shear, so on a cold night you're losing fewer lambs, fewer blowflies, more insectivorous birds, more diverse pastures, deeper rooted perennial grasses in your pastures, that just comes right back to your pocket every time." 
The NCT has about 50,000 hectares of high value conservation land protected on private property in New South Wales. 
Under new land management laws passed last November the NSW Government is replacing the trust with a new legal entity called the Biodiversity Conservation Trust. 
It will manage the NCT estate and will have $240 million to spend on new conservation agreements over the next five years.
